PAL.NAME: Microsoft Windows Server 2012 Hyper-V
PAL.DESCRIPTION: General operating system performance analysis for Microsoft Windows Server 2012 with Hyper-V. Use this for a general analysis of the operating system performance counters.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Guest Computer Processor Analysis
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This analysis checks the processor utilization of guest, virtual computer processors. The "\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time" performance counter is more accurate than using the "% Processor Time" counter within the virtual computer due to clock calculation drift.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time

THRESHOLD.NAME: Hyper-V: High processor utilization of more than 75% on a virtual processor
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorVirtualProcessorPercentGuestRunTimeALL -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 75

THRESHOLD.NAME: Hyper-V: Very high processor utilization of more than 90% on a virtual processor
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorVirtualProcessorPercentGuestRunTimeALL -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 90

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(*)\% Guest Run Time

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Physical Server Processor Analysis
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This analysis checks the processor utilization of physical processors of the host computer. The "\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time" performance counter is more accurate than using the "% Processor Time" counter on the host, root partition computer because the "% Processor Time" counter only measures the processor time of the host, root partition computer only. The "\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time" performance counter is the best counter to use to analyze overall processor utilization of the Hyper-V server.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time

THRESHOLD.NAME: Hyper-V: High processor utilization of more than 75% on a physical processor
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorLogicalProcessorPercentTotalRunTimeALL -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 75

THRESHOLD.NAME: Hyper-V: Very high processor utilization of more than 90% on a physical processor
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorLogicalProcessorPercentTotalRunTimeALL -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 90

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(*)\% Total Run Time

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Physical Server Network Analysis
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
This counter represents the total number of bytes that have traversed the network adapter. Bytes/sec is the rate at which bytes are sent and received over each network adapter both physical and virtual. How quickly you can identify a problem depends on the type of network you have as well as whether you share bandwidth with other applications, services, or virtual computers.

Unlike the Network Interface performance counter object, the connection speed of the virtual network adapters is not exposed as a performance counter, therefore statistics only are provided for this counter. See the Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec alerts to determine if network saturation is occurring on the physical network adapters.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Switch Bytes/Sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of bytes per second traversing the virtual switch.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Read Bytes/second
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of bytes that have been read per second on this virtual device.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Write Bytes/Second
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of bytes that have been written per second on this virtual device.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Error Count
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of errors that have occured on this virtual device.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Greater than 1 error per second on this virtual storage device
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $HyperVVirtualStorageDeviceErrorCountALL -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 1

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Machine Health Summary Health Critical

THRESHOLD.NAME: Equal to or greater than 1 virtual machine is critical
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVVirtualMachineHealthSummaryHealthCritical -Operator 'ge' -Threshold 1

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the number of virtual machines that with critical health.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processors
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of logical processors present in the system.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processors
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of virtual processors present in the system.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Partition Deposited Pages
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of pages deposited into the partition.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V VM Vid Partition Remote Physical Pages

THRESHOLD.NAME: Virtual Machines are using memory from a remote NUMA Node
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVVMVidPartitionRemotePhysicalPages -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 0

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of physical pages not allocated from the preferred NUMA node.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Error Count
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of errors that have occured on this virtual device.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Read Bytes/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of bytes that have been read per second on this virtual device.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Storage Device Write Bytes/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of bytes that have been written per second on this virtual device.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V VM Vid Numa Node ProcessorCount
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of logical processors detected on this NUMA node.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V VM Vid Partition Preferred NUMA Node Index
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V VM Vid Partition(*)\Preferred NUMA Node Index

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V VM Vid Partition(*)\Preferred NUMA Node Index
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V VM Vid Partition(*)\Preferred NUMA Node Index

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V VM Vid Partition(*)\Preferred NUMA Node Index
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V VM Vid Partition(*)\Preferred NUMA Node Index

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The preferred NUMA node index associated with this partition.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor Hypercalls Cost
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time (in nanoseconds) spent processing a hypercall.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor IO Instructions Cost
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\IO Instructions Cost

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(*)\IO Instructions Cost
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(*)\IO Instructions Cost

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(*)\IO Instructions Cost
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(*)\IO Instructions Cost

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time (in nanoseconds) spent processing an IO instruction.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Partition Virtual TLB Flush Entires/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate of flushes of the entire virtual TLB.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM Added Memory
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the cummulative amount of memory added to the VM.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM Average Pressure

THRESHOLD.NAME: Maximum assigned memory is not enough
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVDynamicMemoryVMAveragePressure -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 83

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the average pressure in the VM.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM Removed Memory
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the cummulative amount of memory removed from the VM.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory Balancer Average Pressure

THRESHOLD.NAME: Virtual Machines are doing paging
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVDynamicMemoryBalancerAveragePressure -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 83

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the average pressure on the balancer node.

ANALYSIS.NAME: RemoteFX Root GPU Management Resources: VMs running RemoteFX
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\Resources: VMs running RemoteFX
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Count of virtual machines that have the RemoteFX 3D adapter installed.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\Resources: VMs running RemoteFX
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\Resources: VMs running RemoteFX

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\Resources: VMs running RemoteFX
CHART.DATASOURCE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\Resources: VMs running RemoteFX

ANALYSIS.NAME: RemoteFX Root GPU Management VRAM: Available MB per GPU
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\VRAM: Available MB per GPU

DATASOURCE.NAME: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\VRAM: Available MB per GPU
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\VRAM: Available MB per GPU

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\VRAM: Available MB per GPU
CHART.DATASOURCE: \RemoteFX Root GPU Management(*)\VRAM: Available MB per GPU

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Amount of dedicated VRAM that is unused.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Partition Address Spaces

THRESHOLD.NAME: CPU SLAT compatiblity
THRESHOLD.CODE: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorRootPartitionAddressSpaces -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 0

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of address spaces in the virtual TLB of the partition. If this counter is 0 than your CPU is SLAT compatible

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor Context Switches/sec

THRESHOLD.NAME: Value should be below 20.000 per logical processor
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVHypervisorLogicalProcessorContextSwitchessec -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 20000
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate of virtual processor context switches on the processor.The collected value should be below 20.000 per logical processor.These are the number of times a new Virtual Processor (VP) had been scheduled to a particular Logical Processor (LP).

ANALYSIS.NAME: LogicalDisk Disk Transfers/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Disk Transfers/sec is the rate of read and write operations on the disk. This counter is to messure the IOPs your logical disk have done.
A typical 7.200 rpm SATA disk can do ~75-100 IOPs. A typical 10.000 rpm SATA disk can do ~125-150 IOPs. A typical 15.000 rpm SAS disk can do ~175-210 IOPs.

ANALYSIS.NAME: PhysicalDisk Disk Transfers/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Disk Transfers/sec is the rate of read and write operations on the disk. This counter is to messure the IOPs your logical disk have done.
A typical 7.200 rpm SATA disk can do ~75-100 IOPs. A typical 10.000 rpm SATA disk can do ~125-150 IOPs. A typical 15.000 rpm SAS disk can do ~175-210 IOPs.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM Guest Visible Physical Memory
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Guest Visible Physical Memory

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Guest Visible Physical Memory
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Guest Visible Physical Memory

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Guest Visible Physical Memory
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Guest Visible Physical Memory

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the amount of memory visible in the VM.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM Smart Paging Working Set Size
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Smart Paging Working Set Size

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Smart Paging Working Set Size
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Smart Paging Working Set Size

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Smart Paging Working Set Size
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Hyper-V Dynamic Memory VM(*)\Smart Paging Working Set Size

THRESHOLD.NAME: Hyper-V is doing Smart Paging
THRESHOLD.CODE:
StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVDynamicMemoryVMSmartPagingWorkingSetSize -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 0
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Size of memory backed by Smart Paging in Mbytes.
To minimize the performance impact of Smart Paging, Hyper-V uses it only when all of the following occurs: -The virtual machine is being restarted. -There is no available physical memory. - No memory can be reclaimed from other virtual machines running on the host.

ANALYSIS.NAME: NUMA Node Memory Available MBytes
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Approximate amount of physical memory available for allocation for a NUMA node, in megabytes. Computed as the sum of memory on the zeroed, free, and standby lists for a NUMA node. This counter is available only on 64-bit systems.

THRESHOLD.NAME: A Numa Node has less than 1 GB available
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfNUMANodeMemoryAvailableMBytes -Operator 'lt' -Threshold 1024
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Switch Processor Number of VMQs

THRESHOLD.NAME: VMQ is not enabled or network cards do not support VMQ
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfHyperVVirtualSwitchProcessorNumberofVMQs -Operator 'le' -Threshold 0
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the number of VMQs targeting on the virtual switch processor.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Volume Cache Cache Size - Configured

THRESHOLD.NAME: CSV Cache not enabled
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVVolumeCacheCacheSizeConfigured -Operator 'le' -Threshold 0
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The configured size of the CSV Cache if enabled. If not read this blog to find out how to enable it http://blogs.msdn.com/b/clustering/archive/2012/03/22/10286676.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Volume Cache Cache Size - Current

THRESHOLD.NAME: Check if CSV Cache is enabled
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVVolumeCacheCacheSizeCurrent -Operator 'le' -Threshold 0
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The current size of the CSV Cache. If the value is 0 than CSV cache is not enabled or the CSV disk was not taken offline and online

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Volume Cache Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Cache IO Read - Bytes/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate at which bytes read from cache

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Volume Cache Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of new bytes read from Disk per sec.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Cluster CSV Volume Cache(*)\Disk IO Read - Bytes/Sec

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Replica VM Network Bytes Recv
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total bytes received over the network for the virtual machine since the virtual machine management service was started.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Replica VM Network Bytes Sent
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total bytes sent over the network for the virtual machine since the virtual machine management service was started.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV File System Redirected Read Bytes/sec

THRESHOLD.NAME: CSV in redirected Mode?
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVFileSystemRedirectedReadBytessec -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 1000000
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate at which read were redirected to the volume over the network.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV File System Redirected Write Bytes/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate at which bytes written were redirected to the volume over the network.

THRESHOLD.NAME: CSV in redirected mode?
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVFileSystemRedirectedWriteBytessec -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 1000000
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Volume Cache Cache State

THRESHOLD.NAME: CSV Volume Cache State
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVVolumeCacheCacheState -Operator 'ne' -Threshold 1
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The current state of CSV Cache. 0=disabled, 1=enabled.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster Resource Control Manager RHS Restarts

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster Resource Control Manager RHS Restarts >1
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.

#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster Resource Control Manager RHS Restarts >10
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.

#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The RHS Restarts performance counter shows the number of resource host subsystem process (rhs.exe) restarts.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster NetFt Heartbeats Missing heartbeats
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of missing heartbeats since the last heartbeat was received

THRESHOLD.CODE:

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster NetFt Heartbeats Missing heartbeats >4

#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.

ANALYSIS.NAME: RDMA Completion Queue Errors
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: % C1 Time is the percentage of time the processor spends in the C1 low-power idle state. % C1 Time is a subset of the total processor idle time. C1 low-power idle state enables the processor to maintain its entire context and quickly return to the running state. Not all systems support the % C1 state.

ANALYSIS.NAME: RDMA Connection Errors
RDMA Failed Connection Attempts
Cluster CSV Block Redirection IO Reads/sec

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster CSV Block Redirection IO Reads sec >1
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVBlockRedirectionIOReadssec -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 1
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate at which new reads were performed.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV Block Redirection IO Writes/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate at which new writes were performed.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster CSV Block Redirection IO Writes sec >1
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVBlockRedirectionIOWritessec -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 1
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Virtual Machine Bus Throttle Events
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the total number of times that any partition has been throttled, which is to say that its interrupts were disabled.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Bytes Dropped is the number of bytes dropped on the network adapter.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Cluster CSV File System Volume State
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: State of the volume. Volume can be in one of the following states. 0 - Init state. In that state all files are invalidated and all IOs except volume level IOs are failing. 1 - Paused state. In this state volume will pause any new IO and down-level state is cleaned. 2 - Draining state. In this state volume will pause any new IO, but down-level files are still opened and some down-level IOs might be still in process. 3 - Set down level state. In this state volume will pause any new IO. The down-level state is already reapplied. 4 - Active state. In this state all IO are proceeding as normal.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster CSV FileSystem Volume State <>4
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVFileSystemVolumeState -Operator 'ne' -Threshold 4
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Cluster CSV FileSystem Volume State =3
THRESHOLD.CODE:
#// Use PowerShell code to create alerts when the conditions for this threshold are met. #// Optionally use the variables listed above in the Variables list box. #// If the condition for this threshold is a static value, then use the StaticThreshold() function. #// Otherwise, you will need to manually loop through the counter instance collection object. #// The counter instance collection object has a unique name for each counter data source in this analysis. #// See the variables in the Variables list box above for more information on the counter instance collection object.
#// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfClusterCSVFileSystemVolumeState -Operator 'eq' -Threshold 3
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Hyper-V Replica VM Compression Efficiency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter represents the compression efficiency for the files that has been transferred over the network.
